article.title: Chronic Skeletal Unloading of the Rat Femur: Mechanisms and Functional Consequences of Vascular Remodeling
funding: National Aeronautics and Space Administration Grant NNX12AL41G
article.abstract: Chronic skeletal unloading diminishes hindlimb bone blood flow. The purpose of the present investigation was to determine 1) whether 7 and 14 days of skeletal unloading alters femoral bone and marrow blood flow and vascular resistance during reloading, and 2) whether putative changes in bone perfusion are associated with a gross structural remodeling of the principal nutrient artery (PNA) of the femur.

sections.introduction: The chronic unloading of the skeleton, such as occurs with prolonged bedrest and microgravity, induces a number of alterations to bone, including reductions in bone mass, density, mineralization, trabecular thickness and osteoblastic activity [1–4].
sections.methods: Six-month-old male Sprague-Dawley rats were assigned to 7-d or 14-d hindlimb unloading (HU) or weight-bearing control groups.
sections.results: Body mass was not different among Con (439 ± 11 g), 7-d HU (425 ± 12 g) and 14-d HU (418 ± 10 g) rats.
sections.discussion: Previous work has shown that as little as 10 min of skeletal unloading reduces bone and marrow perfusion of long bones [6].

article.insights_summary: Chronic skeletal unloading decreases bone and marrow blood flow to the femur. Reloading results in a lower bone and marrow blood flow and higher vascular resistance. The lower blood flow is associated with vascular remodeling in the femur.
article.acknowledgments: This study was supported by National Aeronautics and Space Administration Grant NNX12AL41G.
